name: Hydrogen
fact: Hydrogen is the lightest and most abundant element in the universe.

examples.description: Helium is used in party balloons because it's non-flammable and lighter than air.
Helium is used to cool the magnets in MRI machines.

history: Hydrogen was discovered by British scientist Henry Cavendish in the year 1766. The word Hydrogen comes from the French words 'hydr-' meaning water, and -gène meaning producer. This is because when hydrogen gas is burned, it combines with oxygen to create water.
applications: Hydrogen is a main component in rocket fuel. This is because it is light and burns very well.
Hydrogen Peroxide is a sterilizing agent used for cleaning wounds and cuts.

name: Helium
fact: Helium is used to inflate balloons because it's lighter than air.

examples.description: Helium is used in party balloons because it's non-flammable and lighter than air.
Helium is used to cool the magnets in MRI machines.

history: Discovered in 1868 by Pierre Janssen and Norman Lockyer, helium is the second lightest element.

name: Lithium
fact: Lithium is used in rechargeable batteries for phones and laptops.

examples.description: Lithium-ion batteries are widely used in electronics and electric vehicles.
Lithium is used in medications to treat bipolar disorder.

history: Discovered by Johan August Arfwedson in 1817, lithium is the lightest metal.

name: Beryllium
fact: Beryllium is used in aerospace materials due to its strength and lightness.

examples.description: Beryllium-copper alloys are used in springs and connectors.
Beryllium is used in satellite dishes and telescopes.

history: Discovered by Louis-Nicolas Vauquelin in 1798, beryllium is a lightweight but strong metal.

name: Boron
fact: Boron is used in detergents and as a flame retardant.

examples.description: Borax, a compound of boron, is used in laundry detergents.
Boron is used in fiberglass for insulation.

history: Discovered by Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac and Louis Jacques Thénard in 1808, boron is a versatile element.

name: Carbon
fact: Carbon is the basis of all known life on Earth.

examples.description: Diamonds are a form of carbon with a crystalline structure.
Graphite, another form of carbon, is used in pencils.

history: Known since ancient times, carbon is a key element in organic chemistry.

name: Nitrogen
fact: Nitrogen makes up about 78% of Earth's atmosphere.

examples.description: Liquid nitrogen is used in cryogenics.
Nitrogen is a key component of fertilizers.

history: Discovered by Daniel Rutherford in 1772, nitrogen is essential for life.

name: Oxygen
fact: Oxygen is essential for respiration and combustion.

examples.description: Oxygen tanks are used in medical treatments.
Oxygen supports combustion, making fire possible.

history: Discovered independently by Carl Wilhelm Scheele and Joseph Priestley in the 1770s, oxygen is vital for life.

name: Fluorine
fact: Fluorine is the most reactive element.

examples.description: Fluoride, a compound of fluorine, is used in toothpaste.
Teflon, a fluorine compound, is used in non-stick cookware.

history: Discovered by Henri Moissan in 1886, fluorine is highly reactive.

name: Neon
fact: Neon is used in colorful signs and lighting.

examples.description: Neon lights are used in advertising and art.
Neon is used in lasers.

history: Discovered by William Ramsay and Morris Travers in 1898, neon is known for its bright red-orange glow.

name: Sodium
fact: Sodium is a key component of table salt (NaCl).

examples.description: Sodium chloride, or table salt, is essential for human health.
Sodium vapor lamps are used for street lighting.

history: Discovered by Sir Humphry Davy in 1807, sodium is a highly reactive metal.

name: Magnesium
fact: Magnesium is used in fireworks to produce bright white light.

examples.description: Magnesium is used in fireworks for its bright white flame.
Magnesium alloys are used in lightweight car wheels.

history: Discovered by Joseph Black in 1755, magnesium is a lightweight and strong metal.

name: Aluminum
fact: Aluminum is the most abundant metal in Earth's crust.

examples.description: Aluminum foil is used for packaging and cooking.
Aluminum is used in aircraft construction due to its lightness.

history: Discovered by Hans Christian Ørsted in 1825, aluminum is widely used in industry.

name: Silicon
fact: Silicon is used in computer chips and solar panels.

examples.description: Silicon is the primary material in computer chips.
Silicon is used in solar panels to convert sunlight into electricity.

history: Discovered by Jöns Jacob Berzelius in 1824, silicon is a key element in electronics.

name: Phosphorus
fact: Phosphorus is essential for DNA and energy transfer in cells.

examples.description: Phosphorus is used in matchsticks for ignition.
Phosphorus is a key component of fertilizers.

history: Discovered by Hennig Brand in 1669, phosphorus is essential for life.

name: Sulfur
fact: Sulfur is used in gunpowder and matches.

examples.description: Sulfur is a key ingredient in gunpowder.
Sulfur is used in the heads of matches.

history: Known since ancient times, sulfur has been used for thousands of years.

name: Chlorine
fact: Chlorine is used to disinfect swimming pools.

examples.description: Chlorine is used to keep swimming pools clean.
Chlorine is a key ingredient in household bleach.

history: Discovered by Carl Wilhelm Scheele in 1774, chlorine is widely used in sanitation.

name: Argon
fact: Argon is used in light bulbs to prevent filament oxidation.

examples.description: Argon is used in incandescent light bulbs.
Argon is used as a shielding gas in welding.

history: Discovered by Lord Rayleigh and William Ramsay in 1894, argon is an inert gas.

name: Potassium
fact: Potassium is essential for muscle and nerve function.

examples.description: Potassium is found in bananas, which are a good dietary source.
Potassium is a key component of fertilizers.

history: Discovered by Sir Humphry Davy in 1807, potassium is a vital nutrient.

name: Calcium
fact: Calcium is the main component of bones and teeth.

examples.description: Calcium is essential for strong bones and teeth.
Calcium carbonate is used in chalk and antacids.

history: Discovered by Sir Humphry Davy in 1808, calcium is essential for life.

name: Scandium
fact: Scandium is used in aerospace components due to its lightweight and strength.

examples.description: Scandium-aluminum alloys are used in aircraft frames.
Scandium is used in high-performance bicycle frames.

history: Discovered by Lars Fredrik Nilson in 1879, scandium is a rare transition metal.

name: Titanium
fact: Titanium is known for its strength, lightness, and resistance to corrosion.

examples.description: Titanium is used in aircraft engines and frames.
Titanium is used in medical implants due to its biocompatibility.

history: Discovered by William Gregor in 1791, titanium is widely used in industry and medicine.

name: Vanadium
fact: Vanadium is used in steel alloys to increase strength and durability.

examples.description: Vanadium steel is used in construction and tools.
Vanadium is used in redox flow batteries for energy storage.

history: Discovered by Andrés Manuel del Río in 1801, vanadium is a versatile transition metal.

name: Chromium
fact: Chromium is used to make stainless steel and is known for its shiny finish.

examples.description: Chromium is a key component of stainless steel.
Chromium is used in chrome plating for a shiny, corrosion-resistant finish.

history: Discovered by Louis Nicolas Vauquelin in 1797, chromium is widely used in industry.

name: Manganese
fact: Manganese is essential for steel production and is found in batteries.

examples.description: Manganese is used to remove impurities in steel production.
Manganese is used in alkaline and lithium-ion batteries.

history: Discovered by Johan Gottlieb Gahn in 1774, manganese is a key industrial metal.

name: Iron
fact: Iron is the most widely used metal and is essential for blood production.

examples.description: Iron is the primary component of steel, used in construction.
Iron is a key component of hemoglobin, which carries oxygen in blood.

history: Known since ancient times, iron has been used for tools and weapons for thousands of years.

name: Cobalt
fact: Cobalt is used in rechargeable batteries and magnetic alloys.

examples.description: Cobalt is a key component of lithium-ion batteries.
Cobalt is used in strong magnets for motors and generators.

history: Discovered by Georg Brandt in 1735, cobalt is a versatile transition metal.

name: Nickel
fact: Nickel is used in stainless steel and rechargeable batteries.

examples.description: Nickel is a key component of stainless steel.
Nickel is used in nickel-metal hydride batteries.

history: Discovered by Axel Fredrik Cronstedt in 1751, nickel is widely used in industry.

name: Copper
fact: Copper is an excellent conductor of electricity and is used in wiring.

examples.description: Copper is used in electrical wiring due to its conductivity.
Copper is used in coins, such as the U.S. penny.

history: Known since ancient times, copper has been used for thousands of years.

name: Zinc
fact: Zinc is used to galvanize steel and is essential for human health.

examples.description: Zinc is used to coat steel to prevent rusting.
Zinc is an essential nutrient for the immune system.

history: Known since ancient times, zinc has been used for brass and medicinal purposes.

name: Gallium
fact: Gallium melts in your hand due to its low melting point (29.76°C).

examples.description: Gallium is often used in science demonstrations to show its low melting point.
Gallium is used in semiconductors and LEDs.

history: Discovered by Paul-Émile Lecoq de Boisbaudran in 1875, gallium is a unique metal.
applications: Used in LEDs and solar panels.

name: Germanium
fact: Germanium is used in fiber optics and infrared optics.

examples.description: Germanium is used in fiber optic cables for high-speed internet.
Germanium lenses are used in infrared cameras.

history: Discovered by Clemens Winkler in 1886, germanium is a key material in electronics.

name: Arsenic
fact: Arsenic is toxic but has been used in pesticides and wood preservatives.

examples.description: Arsenic compounds were once used in pesticides.
Arsenic is used to preserve wood from insects and decay.

history: Known since ancient times, arsenic has a long history of use and misuse.

name: Selenium
fact: Selenium is essential for human health and is used in photocopiers.

examples.description: Selenium is used in photocopiers and laser printers.
Selenium is an essential nutrient for the human body.

history: Discovered by Jöns Jacob Berzelius in 1817, selenium is a versatile element.

name: Bromine
fact: Bromine is one of only two elements that are liquid at room temperature.

examples.description: Bromine is a reddish-brown liquid at room temperature.
Bromine compounds are used as flame retardants.

history: Discovered by Antoine Jérôme Balard in 1826, bromine is a reactive halogen.

name: Krypton
fact: Krypton is used in high-performance lighting and photography.

examples.description: Krypton is used in camera flashes for bright, white light.
Krypton is used in certain types of lasers.

history: Discovered by William Ramsay and Morris Travers in 1898, krypton is a noble gas.

name: Rubidium
fact: Rubidium is used in atomic clocks and vacuum tubes.

examples.description: Rubidium is used in highly accurate atomic clocks.
Rubidium is used in vacuum tubes for specialized applications.

history: Discovered by Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff in 1861, rubidium is a reactive alkali metal.

name: Strontium
fact: Strontium is used in fireworks to produce bright red colors.

examples.description: Strontium compounds are used in red fireworks.
Strontium is used in some toothpastes for sensitive teeth.

history: Discovered by Adair Crawford in 1790, strontium is known for its vibrant red flame.

name: Yttrium
fact: Yttrium is used in superconductors and LED lights.

examples.description: Yttrium is used in phosphors for LED lights.
Yttrium is used in high-temperature superconductors.

history: Discovered by Johan Gadolin in 1794, yttrium is a versatile transition metal.

name: Zirconium
fact: Zirconium is used in nuclear reactors due to its resistance to corrosion.

examples.description: Zirconium is used in fuel rods for nuclear reactors.
Zirconium is used in jewelry as a diamond substitute.

history: Discovered by Martin Heinrich Klaproth in 1789, zirconium is a corrosion-resistant metal.

name: Niobium
fact: Niobium is used in superconducting magnets and jet engines.

examples.description: Niobium is used in superconducting magnets for MRI machines.
Niobium alloys are used in jet engines for their strength and heat resistance.

history: Discovered by Charles Hatchett in 1801, niobium is a versatile transition metal.

name: Molybdenum
fact: Molybdenum is used in high-strength steel alloys and lubricants.

examples.description: Molybdenum is added to steel to increase strength and heat resistance.
Molybdenum disulfide is used as a dry lubricant.

history: Discovered by Carl Wilhelm Scheele in 1778, molybdenum is a key industrial metal.

name: Technetium
fact: Technetium is the lightest element with no stable isotopes and is used in medical imaging.

examples.description: Technetium-99m is used in medical imaging to diagnose diseases.
Technetium is used in nuclear medicine for diagnostic procedures.

history: Discovered by Carlo Perrier and Emilio Segrè in 1937, technetium was the first artificially produced element.

name: Ruthenium
fact: Ruthenium is used in electronics and as a catalyst in chemical reactions.

examples.description: Ruthenium is used in hard drives for data storage.
Ruthenium is used as a catalyst in the production of ammonia.

history: Discovered by Karl Ernst Claus in 1844, ruthenium is a rare transition metal.

name: Rhodium
fact: Rhodium is used in catalytic converters and jewelry plating.

examples.description: Rhodium is used in catalytic converters to reduce vehicle emissions.
Rhodium is used to plate jewelry for a shiny, tarnish-resistant finish.

history: Discovered by William Hyde Wollaston in 1803, rhodium is a rare and valuable metal.

name: Palladium
fact: Palladium is used in catalytic converters and electronics.

examples.description: Palladium is used in catalytic converters to reduce vehicle emissions.
Palladium is used in capacitors and connectors in electronics.

history: Discovered by William Hyde Wollaston in 1803, palladium is a versatile transition metal.

name: Silver
fact: Silver is the best conductor of electricity and is used in jewelry and electronics.

examples.description: Silver is widely used in jewelry and decorative items.
Silver is used in electrical contacts and conductors.

history: Known since ancient times, silver has been used for currency, jewelry, and utensils.

name: Cadmium
fact: Cadmium is used in rechargeable batteries and pigments.

examples.description: Cadmium is used in nickel-cadmium rechargeable batteries.
Cadmium is used in pigments for paints and plastics.

history: Discovered by Friedrich Stromeyer in 1817, cadmium is a toxic but useful metal.

name: Indium
fact: Indium is used in touchscreens and solar panels.

examples.description: Indium tin oxide is used in touchscreens for its transparency and conductivity.
Indium is used in thin-film solar panels.

history: Discovered by Ferdinand Reich and Hieronymous Theodor Richter in 1863, indium is a rare metal.

name: Tin
fact: Tin is used in solder, food packaging, and bronze alloys.

examples.description: Tin is used in solder for electronics and plumbing.
Tin is used to coat steel cans for food preservation.

history: Known since ancient times, tin has been used in bronze and pewter.

name: Antimony
fact: Antimony is used in flame retardants and batteries.

examples.description: Antimony compounds are used as flame retardants in plastics and textiles.
Antimony is used in lead-acid batteries to improve performance.

history: Known since ancient times, antimony has been used in cosmetics and medicines.

name: Tellurium
fact: Tellurium is used in solar panels and thermoelectric devices.

examples.description: Tellurium is used in cadmium telluride solar panels.
Tellurium is used in thermoelectric devices to convert heat into electricity.

history: Discovered by Franz-Joseph Müller von Reichenstein in 1782, tellurium is a rare metalloid.

name: Iodine
fact: Iodine is essential for thyroid function and is used in disinfectants.

examples.description: Iodine is added to table salt to prevent iodine deficiency.
Iodine is used as an antiseptic to disinfect wounds.

history: Discovered by Bernard Courtois in 1811, iodine is an essential nutrient.

name: Xenon
fact: Xenon is used in high-intensity lamps and anesthesia.

examples.description: Xenon is used in high-intensity discharge lamps for bright, white light.
Xenon is used as an anesthetic in medical procedures.

history: Discovered by William Ramsay and Morris Travers in 1898, xenon is a noble gas.

name: Cesium
fact: Cesium is used in atomic clocks and drilling fluids.

examples.description: Cesium is used in atomic clocks for highly accurate timekeeping.
Cesium compounds are used in drilling fluids for oil exploration.

history: Discovered by Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff in 1860, cesium is a highly reactive alkali metal.

name: Barium
fact: Barium is used in medical imaging and fireworks.

examples.description: Barium sulfate is used in X-ray imaging to visualize the digestive system.
Barium compounds are used in green fireworks.

history: Discovered by Carl Wilhelm Scheele in 1772, barium is a reactive alkaline earth metal.

name: Lanthanum
fact: Lanthanum is used in camera lenses and hydrogen storage.

examples.description: Lanthanum is used in high-quality camera lenses for its optical properties.
Lanthanum is used in hydrogen storage alloys for fuel cells.

history: Discovered by Carl Gustaf Mosander in 1839, lanthanum is the first lanthanide.

name: Cerium
fact: Cerium is used in catalytic converters and self-cleaning ovens.

examples.description: Cerium is used in catalytic converters to reduce vehicle emissions.
Cerium oxide is used in self-cleaning ovens to break down food residues.

history: Discovered by Jöns Jakob Berzelius and Wilhelm Hisinger in 1803, cerium is a versatile lanthanide.

name: Praseodymium
fact: Praseodymium is used in high-strength magnets and colored glass.

examples.description: Praseodymium is used in high-strength magnets for motors and generators.
Praseodymium is used to create yellow-green glass.

history: Discovered by Carl Auer von Welsbach in 1885, praseodymium is a rare earth metal.

name: Neodymium
fact: Neodymium is used in powerful magnets and lasers.

examples.description: Neodymium magnets are the strongest permanent magnets known.
Neodymium is used in high-powered lasers.

history: Discovered by Carl Auer von Welsbach in 1885, neodymium is a key component of rare earth magnets.

name: Promethium
fact: Promethium is a radioactive element used in nuclear batteries.

examples.description: Promethium is used in nuclear batteries for space exploration.
Promethium is used in glow-in-the-dark paints.

history: Discovered by Jacob A. Marinsky, Lawrence E. Glendenin, and Charles D. Coryell in 1945, promethium is a rare radioactive element.

name: Samarium
fact: Samarium is used in magnets and cancer treatment.

examples.description: Samarium-cobalt magnets are used in high-performance motors.
Samarium-153 is used in cancer treatment to relieve pain.

history: Discovered by Paul-Émile Lecoq de Boisbaudran in 1879, samarium is a versatile lanthanide.

name: Europium
fact: Europium is used in fluorescent lamps and TV screens.

examples.description: Europium is used in phosphors for fluorescent lamps.
Europium is used in red and blue phosphors for TV screens.

history: Discovered by Eugène-Anatole Demarçay in 1896, europium is a key element in lighting technology.

name: Gadolinium
fact: Gadolinium is used in MRI contrast agents and nuclear reactors.

examples.description: Gadolinium is used in contrast agents for MRI scans.
Gadolinium is used as a neutron absorber in nuclear reactors.

history: Discovered by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac in 1880, gadolinium is a versatile lanthanide.

name: Terbium
fact: Terbium is used in green phosphors and solid-state devices.

examples.description: Terbium is used in green phosphors for fluorescent lamps.
Terbium is used in solid-state devices for data storage.

history: Discovered by Carl Gustaf Mosander in 1843, terbium is a rare earth metal.

name: Dysprosium
fact: Dysprosium is used in high-strength magnets and nuclear reactors.

examples.description: Dysprosium is used in high-strength magnets for electric vehicles.
Dysprosium is used as a neutron absorber in nuclear reactors.

history: Discovered by Paul-Émile Lecoq de Boisbaudran in 1886, dysprosium is a rare earth metal.

name: Holmium
fact: Holmium is used in lasers and nuclear control rods.

examples.description: Holmium is used in medical lasers for surgery.
Holmium is used in nuclear control rods to regulate reactions.

history: Discovered by Marc Delafontaine and Jacques-Louis Soret in 1878, holmium is a rare earth metal.

name: Erbium
fact: Erbium is used in fiber optics and lasers.

examples.description: Erbium is used in fiber optic cables for high-speed internet.
Erbium is used in medical and dental lasers.

history: Discovered by Carl Gustaf Mosander in 1843, erbium is a versatile lanthanide.

name: Thulium
fact: Thulium is used in portable X-ray machines and lasers.

examples.description: Thulium is used in portable X-ray machines.
Thulium is used in medical lasers for surgery.

history: Discovered by Per Teodor Cleve in 1879, thulium is a rare earth metal.

name: Ytterbium
fact: Ytterbium is used in atomic clocks and stress gauges.

examples.description: Ytterbium is used in highly accurate atomic clocks.
Ytterbium is used in stress gauges for measuring pressure.

history: Discovered by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac in 1878, ytterbium is a versatile lanthanide.

name: Lutetium
fact: Lutetium is used in cancer treatment and petroleum refining.

examples.description: Lutetium-177 is used in targeted cancer therapies.
Lutetium is used as a catalyst in petroleum refining.

history: Discovered by Georges Urbain and Carl Auer von Welsbach in 1907, lutetium is the last lanthanide.

name: Hafnium
fact: Hafnium is used in nuclear reactors and computer chips.

examples.description: Hafnium is used in control rods for nuclear reactors.
Hafnium is used in high-performance computer chips.

history: Discovered by Dirk Coster and George de Hevesy in 1923, hafnium is a corrosion-resistant metal.

name: Tantalum
fact: Tantalum is used in capacitors and surgical implants.

examples.description: Tantalum capacitors are used in electronics for their reliability.
Tantalum is used in surgical implants due to its biocompatibility.

history: Discovered by Anders Gustaf Ekeberg in 1802, tantalum is a highly corrosion-resistant metal.

name: Tungsten
fact: Tungsten has the highest melting point of all metals and is used in light bulb filaments.

examples.description: Tungsten is used in incandescent light bulb filaments.
Tungsten carbide is used in drill bits for its hardness.

history: Discovered by Juan José and Fausto Elhuyar in 1783, tungsten is known for its strength and heat resistance.

name: Rhenium
fact: Rhenium is used in jet engines and catalysts.

examples.description: Rhenium is used in superalloys for jet engine components.
Rhenium is used as a catalyst in the production of lead-free gasoline.

history: Discovered by Walter Noddack, Ida Tacke, and Otto Berg in 1925, rhenium is one of the rarest elements.

name: Osmium
fact: Osmium is the densest naturally occurring element and is used in fountain pen tips.

examples.description: Osmium is used in fountain pen tips for its durability.
Osmium is used in electron microscopy for staining samples.

history: Discovered by Smithson Tennant in 1803, osmium is a dense and hard metal.

name: Iridium
fact: Iridium is used in spark plugs and as a catalyst.

examples.description: Iridium is used in spark plugs for its high melting point.
Iridium is used as a catalyst in chemical reactions.

history: Discovered by Smithson Tennant in 1803, iridium is one of the most corrosion-resistant metals.

name: Platinum
fact: Platinum is used in catalytic converters and jewelry.

examples.description: Platinum is used in catalytic converters to reduce vehicle emissions.
Platinum is used in high-end jewelry for its luster and durability.

history: Known since ancient times, platinum is a precious metal used in jewelry and industry.

name: Gold
fact: Gold is used in jewelry, electronics, and as a financial asset.

examples.description: Gold is widely used in jewelry for its beauty and resistance to tarnish.
Gold is used in electronics for its excellent conductivity.

history: Known since ancient times, gold has been used as currency and in jewelry for thousands of years.

name: Mercury
fact: Mercury is the only metal that is liquid at room temperature and is used in thermometers.

examples.description: Mercury is used in thermometers for its uniform expansion.
Mercury is used in barometers to measure atmospheric pressure.

history: Known since ancient times, mercury has been used in alchemy and scientific instruments.

name: Thallium
fact: Thallium is highly toxic and was once used in rat poison.

examples.description: Thallium sulfate was once used as a rat poison.
Thallium is used in infrared lenses for cameras.

history: Discovered by Sir William Crookes in 1861, thallium is a toxic post-transition metal.

name: Lead
fact: Lead is used in batteries and radiation shielding.

examples.description: Lead-acid batteries are widely used in vehicles.
Lead is used in radiation shielding for X-rays and nuclear reactors.

history: Known since ancient times, lead has been used in pipes, paints, and weights.

name: Bismuth
fact: Bismuth is used in cosmetics and pharmaceuticals.

examples.description: Bismuth oxychloride is used in cosmetics for its pearlescent effect.
Bismuth subsalicylate is the active ingredient in Pepto-Bismol.

history: Known since ancient times, bismuth is a post-transition metal with unique properties.

name: Polonium
fact: Polonium is highly radioactive and was used in the assassination of Alexander Litvinenko.

examples.description: Polonium is used as a radioactive heat source in space probes.
Polonium is used in static eliminators for industrial applications.

history: Discovered by Marie and Pierre Curie in 1898, polonium is a highly radioactive element.

name: Astatine
fact: Astatine is the rarest naturally occurring element on Earth.

examples.description: Astatine is used in cancer treatment due to its radioactivity.
Astatine is studied for its potential use in targeted alpha therapy.

history: Discovered by Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, and Emilio Segrè in 1940, astatine is a rare halogen.

name: Radon
fact: Radon is a radioactive gas that can cause lung cancer.

examples.description: Radon testing kits are used to detect radon levels in homes.
Radon is used in cancer treatment in controlled environments.

history: Discovered by Friedrich Ernst Dorn in 1900, radon is a radioactive noble gas.

name: Francium
fact: Francium is the second rarest naturally occurring element and is highly radioactive.

examples.description: Francium is studied in nuclear physics due to its extreme rarity.
Francium is used in atomic structure research.

history: Discovered by Marguerite Perey in 1939, francium is a highly reactive alkali metal.

name: Radium
fact: Radium was once used in glow-in-the-dark paints but is highly radioactive.

examples.description: Radium was used in glow-in-the-dark paints for watches and instruments.
Radium is used in cancer treatment in controlled environments.

history: Discovered by Marie and Pierre Curie in 1898, radium is a highly radioactive element.

name: Actinium
fact: Actinium is used in cancer treatment and as a neutron source.

examples.description: Actinium-225 is used in targeted cancer therapies.
Actinium is used as a neutron source in scientific research.

history: Discovered by André-Louis Debierne in 1899, actinium is a radioactive actinide.

name: Thorium
fact: Thorium is used in nuclear reactors and as a potential future energy source.

examples.description: Thorium is used in nuclear reactors as a fuel source.
Thorium is being researched as a sustainable energy source.

history: Discovered by Jöns Jakob Berzelius in 1828, thorium is a radioactive actinide.
applications: Studied as a future energy source.

name: Protactinium
fact: Protactinium is a rare and highly radioactive element used in scientific research.

examples.description: Protactinium is studied for its nuclear properties.
Protactinium is used in nuclear research.

history: Discovered by Kasimir Fajans and Oswald Helmuth Göhring in 1913, protactinium is a rare actinide.

name: Uranium
fact: Uranium is used as fuel in nuclear reactors and in atomic bombs.

examples.description: Uranium is used as fuel in nuclear power plants.
Uranium-235 is used in atomic bombs.

history: Discovered by Martin Heinrich Klaproth in 1789, uranium is a key element in nuclear energy.

name: Neptunium
fact: Neptunium is a byproduct of nuclear reactors and is used in research.

examples.description: Neptunium is produced in nuclear reactors.
Neptunium is studied for its nuclear properties.

history: Discovered by Edwin McMillan and Philip H. Abelson in 1940, neptunium is a synthetic actinide.

name: Plutonium
fact: Plutonium is used in nuclear reactors and atomic bombs.

examples.description: Plutonium is used as fuel in nuclear reactors.
Plutonium-239 is used in atomic bombs.

history: Discovered by Glenn T. Seaborg, Edwin McMillan, Joseph W. Kennedy, and Arthur Wahl in 1940, plutonium is a key element in nuclear technology.

name: Americium
fact: Americium is used in smoke detectors and as a neutron source.

examples.description: Americium-241 is used in smoke detectors.
Americium is used as a neutron source in scientific research.

history: Discovered by Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, and Albert Ghiorso in 1944, americium is a synthetic actinide.

name: Curium
fact: Curium is used in scientific research and as a power source in space probes.

examples.description: Curium is used as a power source in space probes.
Curium is studied for its radioactive properties.

history: Discovered by Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, and Albert Ghiorso in 1944, curium is a synthetic actinide.

name: Berkelium
fact: Berkelium is used in scientific research and has no commercial applications.

examples.description: Berkelium is studied for its nuclear properties.
Berkelium is produced in particle accelerators.

history: Discovered by Glenn T. Seaborg, Stanley G. Thompson, and Albert Ghiorso in 1949, berkelium is a synthetic actinide.

name: Californium
fact: Californium is used in neutron sources and cancer treatment.

examples.description: Californium-252 is used as a neutron source.
Californium is used in cancer treatment in controlled environments.

history: Discovered by Glenn T. Seaborg, Stanley G. Thompson, and Albert Ghiorso in 1950, californium is a synthetic actinide.

name: Einsteinium
fact: Einsteinium is used in scientific research and has no commercial applications.

examples.description: Einsteinium is studied for its nuclear properties.
Einsteinium is produced in particle accelerators.

history: Discovered by Albert Ghiorso and his team in 1952, einsteinium is a synthetic actinide.
